headline: KY STILL SEEKING TO OPPOSE THIEU
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky played tennis today while his campaign workers were out drumming up support. But his chances of appearing on the presidential ballot in Octo ber appeared to be diminishing.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: For Young Readers: In American terms, 40 million war victims
lead_paragraph: In the past 25 years, from the French naval bombardment of Hai phong harbor, in November, 1946, to the daily American bombings in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, west ern peoples have been killing, maiming, devastating Asian peoples in one of the most savage wars in history. In this quarter‐century, to tal casualties in killed and wounded have reached almost two million, while four million Vietnamese have been uprooted from their homes and villages. The terrible toll of the war has thus directly struck at some six million individuals, almost one out of every five inhabitants of Vietnam. In comparable American terms that would mean 40 million war victims, if ever the United States were to be hit as hard as we have hit the suffering people of Vietnam.
author: By David Schoenbrun

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The closing days of July have seen a staggering amount of politically damaging economic news coming out of the Nixon Administra tion. No wonder the Democrats— despite their own responsibility for much of the situation — believe the economy will be their big gun against the President next year.
author: By John H. Allan

headline: U.S. Patrol Reports 3 Killed in Ambush In Hills at Danang
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 1 (AP) — North Vietnamese troops ambushed a United States patrol in the coastal hills south of Danang yesterday, killing three Ameri cans and wounding eight, the United States command report ed today.

headline: Leaving War to Civilians
lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. The soul‐searching evoked by publication of excerpts from the McNamara report has pro duced a new rash of criticism of our Vietnam venture. Where did we go wrong? is the question of the hour.
author: By Thomas A. Lane

headline: McGovern Cites Advice To Ellsberg on Papers
lead_paragraph: Senator George Mc Govern says it was he who suggested that Daniel Ells berg make the Pentagon papers available to “a re spectable newspaper.”

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — At 6 P.M. last Monday, after his 50 invited guests had sipped their beer, cola and orange juice, Gen. Duong Van Minh stepped on to the steps of his villa in downtown Saigon to an nounce that he had “definite ly and officially” decided to run for President of South Vietnam. “Big Minh,” the man with the best chance of up setting President Nguyen Van Thieu at the polls, finally de cided to take that chance.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: P.O.W. LIST PLEDGED IF U.S. SETS DEADLINE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 31 (AP)—The Vietcong have promised for the first time to identify all the United States war prisoners as soon as the United States sets a deadline for the total with drawal of its troops from Vietnam.

headline: PEKING ARMY SAYS U.S. MUST QUIT ASIA
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Aug. 1 — Despite President Nixon's recent efforts to establish normal relations with China, powerful officials of the People's Liberation Army are mounting a campaign for total withdrawal of United States troops not only from Tai wan and Vietnam but also from Korea, Japan the Philippines and Thailand.
author: By James Reston Special to The New York Times

headline: COMBAT DUTY ENDS FOR 2,990 MORE G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (AP)—The United States command pulled seven more Army units out of combat to day, cutting American troop strength in Vietnam by 2,990 men. The withdrawal was the biggest in a month.

headline: Compromised Draft Bill
lead_paragraph: A House‐Senate conference committee has substantially weakened the Mansfield amendment to the Selective Service Act by eliminating its forthright call for the withdrawal of all United States military forces from Indochina within nine months, subject to the release American prisoners of war. This and other changes in the Mansfield version, which was adopted by the Senate by a 57‐42 vote, leave the President broad leeway in the conduct of the war.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: L. F. E. Goldie

headline: Kennedy Library Opens Most of Its Files
lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 1— The John F. Kennedy Presi dential Library has opened virtually the entire official White House files— except for secret papers—spanning the years of the Kennedy Adminis tration, from Jan. 20, 1961, to Nov. 22, 1963.
author: By Henry Raymont Special to The New York Times

headline: M'GOVERN SEEKS WISCONSIN VOTES
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1—Sen ator George McGovern cam paigned through the paper‐mill towns and family farms of Wis consin this weekend, pressing his few but important advan tages in the race for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: CALLEY SAID TO FACE A 20–30‐YEAR TERM
lead_paragraph: Newsweek Magazine, in its current issue, reports that the life sentence imposed on First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for his role in the Mylai massacre will be reduced to 20 to 30 years by Lieut. Gen. Albert Connor, the Third Army com mander, who is the reviewing officer.

headline: For Women in the Military, New Attractions
lead_paragraph: Yes, the young woman is still joining the armed forces. But even before she steps foot in a recruiter's office these days, she generally has two hurdles to overcome: Strong antimilitary pressure from friends who are disillusioned with the war in Vietnam, and objections from parents who remember that some military women had unattractive reputa tions during World War II.
author: By Judy Klemesrud

headline: Rewards Up to $11,000 Set for Captured Vietcong
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1—The United States and South Vietnam have decided to start paying the highest cash rewards of the war—up to the equivalent of $11,000—for in formation leading to the cap ture of certain key leaders of the Vietcong's political under ground.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: CLASH IS REPORTED IN CAMBODIA SWEEP
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP)—New fighting was reported today in eastern Cam bodia, where 3,500 South Viet namese infantrymen launched a sweep operation six days ago.

headline: A FOURTH CANDIDATE ENTERS SAIGON RACE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 — A fourth candidate for South Vietnam's presiden tial elections has appeared with out fanfare here, and some po litical sources speculate that he is a token rival promoted and helped by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

headline: Bergen Record Ends Use Of William Buckley Column
lead_paragraph: William F. Buckley's syndi cated column, “On the Right,” has been dropped by The Rec ord, a New Jersey newspaper published in Hackensack. The Record explained in an editorial that it had taken the decision because Mr. Buckley had “de stroyed the credibility of his own publication”—National Re view, the conservative mag azine—by the publication of false “secret documents.”

headline: SENTENCE UPHELD IN SECRETS CASE
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) — A finding of contempt of court against Anthony J. Russo, who has refused to testify be fore a Federal grand jury that is investigating the leak of the Pentagon papers, was affirmed today by a panel of three Feder al judges.

headline: EX‐SOLDIERS REPORT VIETNAM SLAYINGS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2—Two former military ‐ intelligence agents asserted today that Vietnamese were indiscrimi nately rounded up, tortured and murdered by Americans in an effort to eliminate Viet cong cadres.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: Ever since publication of the Penta gon papers, Government people have been complaining about the press in vading the Government's privacy. “Un thinkable,” said an F.B.I. man. “Un thinkable to have a situation where people cannot even write memos in the privacy of Government offices without some newspaper getting hold of the material.”
author: By Russell Baker

headline: New Drive by Laotian Army Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 2— Western military sources re ported today a determined push by the Laotian Army toward the town of Pak Song, a key control point on the Boloven Plateau in the southern pan handle. Pak Song and the plateau were overrun by North Vietnamese anti Pathet Lao forces in May.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Maurice H. Stans, the Sec retary of Commerce, yester day appointed John L. Jen kins, a black official of the department, to head minority business programs, thus end ing a behind‐the‐scenes strug gle over the position.
author: Albin Krebs

headline: Vietnam Election
lead_paragraph: Failure to replace promptly the resigning chief nego tiator in Paris with his designated successor, Ambassador Porter, suggests that Washington may be deliberately delaying a serious reply to the new peace proposals submitted by the Communists one month ago. One apparent reason would be an Administration hope that the forthcoming presidential election in South Vietnam, scheduled for Oct. 3, will somehow strengthen the allied position for a negotiated settlement, or even for a satisfactory resolution of the conflict without negotia tions. The way the election campaign is shaping up today, there is little evidence to sustain that hope.

headline: China Reported Preparing Flexible Strategy for Nixon
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Aug. 3—Be hind a screen of tough polem ics and propaganda, China's leaders are reported formulat ing a flexible strategy for their encounter with President Nixon.
author: By Ian Stewart Special to The New York Times

headline: Pearl S. Buck: The Two Chinas
lead_paragraph: PERKASIE, Pa.—Time changes everything. This is a trite saying but it is annoying to realize how true trite sayings are. Verily there is nothing new under the sun! The United States now agrees to the admission of Com munist China into the United Nations. Communist China will be admitted.
author: By Pearl S. Buck

headline: Drug Use Up Among Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 31—Some friends of Tran Tan, aged 15, who worked with him in a bar frequented by American soldiers asked him to sniff some white powder they were peddling. It made him feel strong and happy. Within a month he was injecting heroin into his arm twice a day.

headline: TRIAL FOR DESERTION BEGINS FOR EX‐P.O.W.
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 3 (AP)—The trial of Marine Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney of West Baby lon, L. I., began today one day ahead of schedule, after a sur prise move by the defense to waive trial by a court‐martial board and have the evidence heard by a military judge alone.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Edward Clarke

headline: Court Voids Radio‐TV Ban on Controversial Paid Ads
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — The United States Court of Ap peals here ruled today that radio and television networks and stations must stop refusing to sell advertising time to political parties, antiwar advo cates and other groups that wish to buy time to broadcast controversial messages.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John D. Constable

headline: 3 Vietnam Veterans Ask Raids on P O.W. Camps
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — Three soldiers told a House committee today of spending “agonizing” months chained in side jungle cages as prisoners of the Vietcong and voiced the hope that the United States would carry out more forays like last year's raid on a North Vietnames prisoner of war camp.

headline: U.S. Voluntary Unit Leaving Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3—After 15 years in South Vietnam, one of the best known American volunteer organizations here, whose members have often attacked United States policy and the Indochina war, is being shut down.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: LONDON—In preparing its assess ment as a preliminary to warming up Sino‐American relations, the White House appears to have concluded that any kind of Chinese military descent into Southeast Asia is most improbable for at least the next five years, at very minimum, and indeed is unlikely for years to come.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Allied Planes Level 2 of Enemy's Cambodian Havens
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (AP)—Allied aircraft leveled two Cambodian vil lages today and drove out North Vietnamese and Viet cong soldiers blocking a South Vietnamese advance in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign an Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4—Following is the transcript of President Nixon's news conference today:

headline: Some G.I.'s Are Said to Enter Service as Addicts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4—Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, the President's adviser on narcotics, told Senate subcommittee today that many American service men using drugs in South Viet nam were doing so before they entered the military service.

headline: Marine on Trial for Desertion Described as Unfit for Combat
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 4—A young marine charged with de sertion and disloyalty was de scribed by prosecution wit nesses today as a man who should not have been sent into combat in South Vietnam.
author: By Walter Rugaber Special to The New York Times

headline: Intimidation on Election Charged in a Delta Town
lead_paragraph: BACLIEU, South Vietnam, Aug. 1—A group of citizens in this southern Mekong Delta town charge that the province chief is using his sweeping pow ers to intimidate voters into backing pro‐Government candi dates in the lower house elec tion set for Aug. 29.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Report of Plan to Free P.O.W.'s Disputed by U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 — A Swedish newspaper reported that 183 American prisoners of war would be released by North Vietnam and returned to the United States, but the White House said tonight it could not confirm the report.

headline: 5,000 South Vietnamese Troops Search Jungles Northeast of Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 4 (AP)—Five thousand South Vietnamese paratroop ers have moved into the jun gles northeast of Saigon to check on North Vietnamese infiltration and search for en emy supply depots.

headline: Pravda Charges That the U.S. Press Obeyed Order to Stop Further Publication of Pentagon Papers
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Aug. 4 — Soviet readers were told today that the American press had stopped publishing further Vietnam rev elations from the Pentagon pa pers because someone finally clicked the switch and ordered a halt.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: TRIAL IN LOS ANGELES URGED FOR ELLSBERG
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Aug 4 (AP) — A Federal magistrate said today that Daniel Ellsberg should be returned to California to face charges of illegal possession of the Pentagon papers he said he gave to the press.

headline: Court‐Martial of Mylai Colonel Recessed Alter Jury Is Picked
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 4 The court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson on charges arising from the killings of civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 got under way today with selection of a seven‐mem ber jury of officers.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: In News Conference, He Sees Hope of Dialogue Despite Wide Rift
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4—Pres ident Nixon cautioned today against speculation that his forthcoming journey to Peking would produce “instant détente” with China or a settlement of the Vietnam war.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Premier Denies Intimidation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Aug. 4 (AP) — A communiqué issued by the of: fice of Premier Tran Thien Khiem denied last night that there had been any Government intimidation of province and city councilmen.

headline: Ky Officially Enters Presidential Candidacy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 4—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky officially entered his candidacy for the presidency today, but the Supreme Court must still decide whether he can run.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Catholic Theologian Quits Vietnam Presidential Race
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 4—Dr. Tran Tam, a Roman Catholic theologian who in two weeks quietly gathered nearly enough legislative support to qualify for South Vietnam's presidential election, withdrew from the race today. He hinted that, at the last moment, he did not have enough signatures to qualify.

headline: The Story Behind The Bombing
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — There has been so much discussion about the Pentagon papers recently that I thought I had better get my comments in while the subject is still hot. It is important to begin by defining exactly what we ere talking about when we say “The Penta gon papers.”
author: By U.s. Grant Sharp

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5—The pre‐election maneuver ing here, with all its confusion and uncertainty, has at least served to illustrate again what officials concede is the decline in Washington's leverage on the Government of President Nguy en Van Thieu.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: CANDIDACY OF KY BARRED BY COURT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today lost a major round in his fight to get on the ballot for the presidential elec tion Oct. 3. The South Viet namese Supreme Court re jected his application for can didacy on the ground that it did not comply with the rules established in a stiff electoral law sponsored by Mr. Ky's chief rival, President Nguyen Van Thieu.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: James D. Wiles

headline: 5 AMERICANS KILLED BY MINE IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 6—Five American soldiers were killed and two were wounded when a United States armored personnel car rier from the 196 Brigade, Americal Division, struck a mine yesterday 26 miles south of Danang, the United States command reported today.

headline: Ellsberg Is Ordered to Stand Trial on the Coast
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)—A United States District Court judge today ordered Dr. Daniel Ellsberg removed to Los An geles Aug. 16 to face charges of illegal possession of secret Government documents in the Pentagon papers case.

headline: BID TO FLY P.O.W.'S REMAINS MYSTERY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 — The mystery deepened today over the identity of the person who asked the Swedish airlines office in Bonn, Germany, three weeks ago to arrange a charter flight to Laos to fly. 187 un identified persons to Rome.
author: By Benjamin Welles Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ... and Senate Tortoise
lead_paragraph: Handicapped by its own leisurely debating rules— including such oddities as the filibuster—the Senate is expected to plod along almost to the end of the year. But beyond what it may do about the legislation men tioned above, it can already point to at least two impor tant achievements. It has focused sharply on the issue of where the power to make war resides in the American democracy and it has passed almost unanimously a bill that the National Committee for an Effective Congress hails as “the first realistic campaign finance law” in the country's history.

headline: House Investigation Sought In ‘Today’ Ouster of Jessel
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) —Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, who is chairman of the House Interstate and For eign Commerce Committee, was asked today to investigate last Friday's incident on NBC‐TV's “Today Show” in which George Jessel, the comedian, was re moved from the show after making remarks about The New York Times and The Washing ton Post.

headline: Over 150 War Protesters Are Arrested Near Boston
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 6 (UPI) — More than 150 per sons protesting the Vietnam war were arrested without in cident today at the four gates leading to Hanscom Field.

headline: China Said to Want Accord On Key Issues Before Ties
lead_paragraph: China is understood to have decided to refrain from establishing diplomatic relations or engaging in significant trade with the United States until major political and secu‐ rity problems involving the two nations are settled.
author: By Tad Szulc

headline: Thieu Reported Confident of 55% of Vote
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6 — President Nguyen Van Thieu is reportedly going into the presidential election in October confident that he will win with 55 per cent of the vote, now that Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky apparently has been eliminated from the con tention and Mr. Thieu's only opponent is Gen. Duong Van Minh.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Russo Wins Delay
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) —Anthony J. Russo, the re search analyst who refused to testify before a grand jury in the Pentagon papers case, was granted a temporary reprieve from prison today by Justice Hugo L. Black.

headline: U.S. Contacting TV Source Of Report on Prisoners
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reu ters)—The State Department plans to contact a West German businessman who played a role in reports yesterday that Hanoi might release 187 United States prisoners of war.

headline: Fulbright and Laird at Odds on Military Aid Data
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6—De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird told the Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee today that the Defense Department did not have a current five‐year plan for military assistance and therefore could not provide one as requested by the committee.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Appeals Judge Delays Ruling on Ellsberg
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6— Judge Frank M. Coffin of the United States Court of Appeals said today that he would con sult with at least one of the two other appeals judges be fore ruling on a petition by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Three years ago this month, in 4 hotel in Miami Beach, other members of the New Jersey delegation to the Re publican National Conven tion pleaded in vain with Nelson G. Gross to remain committed to the favorite son candidacy of Senator Clifford P. Case, who was trying to hold the delegation together for Governor Rocke feller. When the floor vote came, Mr. Gross switched to Richard M. Nixon, breaking the delegation and dashing any possibility that Mr. Rockefeller might block Mr. Nixon's nomination on the first ballot.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: First U.S. Unit in War Ends Its Combat Role
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6—The last troops of the first United States Army unit to enter the Vietnam war, over five years ago, pulled out of the field today in preparation for the trip home.

headline: Saigon Units Report Killing 68 in Battles In Eastern Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Aug. 7 (AP)—A South Vietnamese armored column, reinforced by infantrymen, bat tled North Vietnamese and Viet cong troops yesterday in a fresh outbreak of fighting in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Nixon Seeks Better Nursing Homes
lead_paragraph: NASHUA,. N. H., Aug. 6 — President Nixon, announced here today a series of steps using Federal funds to super vise and improve conditions in nursing homes around the country.

headline: JURY MAY WIDEN ELLSBERG INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7—A secret Federal grand jury re sumed its investigation here this week into how the Penta gon papers were made public.

headline: Bunker to Fly to U.S. To Confer with Nixon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 (AP) — Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker will leave Saigon tomorrow for Wash ington to confer with Presi dent Nixon and other top officials, a United States Embassy spokesman said to day. Mr. Bunker is expected to remain in Washington about a week.

headline: Koster Assumes New Post
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Md., Aug. 7 (AP) —Brig. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, who commanded the Americal Division at the time of the My lai slayings in Vietnam, has re ported to his new job as deputy commanding general and chief of staff at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground. He was re duced in rank from major gen eral by former Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor on May 19 for failure to adequately in vestigate the killings.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — President Ngu yen Van Thieu won the first round of his re‐election bid last week when he knocked his rival and long‐time en emy, Vice President Nguyen Cab Ky, out of the race be fore the campaign had even begun. And he did it a little more smoothly and a little more ruthlessly than his op ponents or the American Em bassy had expected.
author: — Iver Petersen

headline: Allies Report Advances in Cambodia and Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 (AP)—South Vietnamese troops in eastern Cambodia and Government troops in Laos re portedly advanced today in of fensives aimed at disrupting en emy supply lines. In South Viet nam the United States com mand reported a mortar attack against an American unit.

headline: Clark Clifford ‘Sounds the Alarm’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON.
author: By Patrick Anderson

headline: Immolation Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 (UPI)—Two Saigon newspa pers reported today that a Buddhist monk burned himself to death in a protest against the war in Quangtin Province, 340 miles northeast of Saigon..

headline: U.S. Jets Attack Gun Positions In Northin ‘Protective Reaction’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Monday, Aug. 9 (AP) — Two American supersonic fighter bombers yesterday attacked antiaircraft emplacements six miles inside North Vietnam that had fired on an American re connaisance jet, the United States command announced to day.

headline: YOUTH VOTE DRIVE SLOWED IN TEXAS
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 8— “Countdown '72,” an effort to register voters under 21 in the hope of electing candidates who will end the war in Vietnam, arrived in Texas this weekend and became embroiled in a dis pute over local strategy and tactics.

headline: Mrs. Binh: Our Plan for Peace
lead_paragraph: PARIS—The Paris four‐party confer ence on Vietnam has held over 120 sessions and, if counted in days, has lasted two and one‐half years. In the meantime, the war is still going on in South Vietnam and has been ex panded to Cambodia and Laos. The South Vietnam people still have to live in rains of bombs, destruction, and death. American youths continue to die on battlefields and to destroy themselves with drugs out of despair and frustration.
author: By Nguyen Thi Binh

headline: 3 Democrats in New Hampshire Stress Economics
lead_paragraph: HOLLIS, N. H., Aug. 8—Three of the leading Democratic can didates and potential candidates for the Presidency seemed to day to agree that economic is sues would dominate the 1972 campaign against President Nixon.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard H. Moore

headline: Pro‐Ky Newspaper Blames Thieu for Confiscations
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8—Late each afternoon recently South Vietnamese po licemen have arrived at the central newspaper distributing market to confiscate the daily Lap Truong.

headline: Official Transcript of the Wide‐Ranging Interview With Premier Chou in Peking
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Aug. 9—Following is a transcript of a recorded interview with Premier Chou En‐lai of China conducted Thursday night by James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times. The conversation, took place in Mr. Chou's reception hall here, and the translator was Chi Chao‐chu, a former Harvard student who is on the Premier's staff. Mr. Chou authorized the official transcript on the condition that both questions and answers be printed verbatim.

headline: L. B. J. and the Commitment Myth
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—There are myths on which the Pentagon Papers shed no light that need to be dispelled since they were important factors in mobi lizing public opinion in support of our war policy. The principal myth is that the United States had commitments to intervene militarily in. Vietnam.
author: By Ernest Gruening

headline: McCloskey Opens His Office in New Hampshire
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 9 (AP)—Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, opened his Presi dential campaign headquar ters today and said President Nixon could end the Indo china war within three days by ac cepting a single prin ciple.

headline: Drag Tests Facing G.I.'s On Temporary Leaves
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 9 (AP)—The United States Army announced to day that its anti‐narcotics program would be expanded to include tests aimed at de tecting addicts in groups leaving Vietnam for 14‐day leaves in the United States.

headline: An Evening With the Premier of China
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Aug. 9—The Pre mier of China is an austere man with thick John L. Lewis eyebrows, cool and inquisi tive dark brown eyes and very white, expressive hands.

headline: JUDGE DISMISSES DESERTION CHARGE
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 9 (AP)—A military judge dis missed today a charge of deser tion against Marine Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney.

headline: Chou Looks to Broad Talks With Nixon
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Aug. 9—Premier Chou En‐lai is prepared for a very broad discussion of world problems when President Nixon comes here some time before May.
author: By James Reston Special to The New York Times

headline: Sensors to Detect Foe Are Proving Value in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 9 (UPI) — A tiny radio transmitter, buried in the red clay floor of an Indochina jungle with only its camou flaged antenna protruding, “bleeped” and thousands of South Vietnamese troops got marching orders.

headline: Labor Bids Nixon Restudy Peking Policy
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10— The executive, council of the A.F.L. ‐ C.I.O. urged President Nixon today to re‐examine his new policy toward Communist China.
author: By Robert A. Wright Special to The New York Times

headline: Asians Doubt That US. Can Halt Heroin Flow
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 10 —Formidable obstacles con front the United States in its efforts to halt the flow of heroin to its troops in Vietnam and to prevent Southeast Asian heroin from moving into the American market to fill the gap that may be left if the traffic from the Middle East is con tained.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: ELLSBERG'S PETITION DENIED BY U.S. JUDGE
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 10 — The United States Court of Ap peals for the First District to day denied the petition‐ of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg to compel Boston Federal district judge to hold a hearing to determine whether illegal wiretapping had been used to obtain an indict ment against him.

headline: COURT‐MARTIAL TOLD OF STRESS ON MARINE
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 10 (AP)—Three psychiatrists at the court‐martial of Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney testified today that the former prisoner of war had made two attempts at suicide because of his “grossly de pressed” state.

headline: Ground Action in Vietnam Continues to Remain Light
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP)—Battlefield action in South Vietnam remained light today, with the only sig nificant clash reported from a Mekong Delta village where Vietcong guerrillas sought to collect “tax” money from the residents.

headline: Jackson Sees Peril Of Party Take‐Over By Democratic Left
lead_paragraph: Senator Henry M. Jackson warned yesterday that the Democratic left was trying to take over the party and that if it succeded the Democrats would lose in 1972 and be in “deep trouble” for years there after.
author: By Damon Stetson

headline: Thieu Asks for Death For Narcotics Dealers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP) — President Nguyen Van Thieu proposed a bill today that would make dealing in narcotics a war time crime and would decree the death penalty for import ers and peddlers belonging to organized rings.

headline: THIEU FOES SEEK A ONEIAN RACE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10—The political opposi tion in South Vietnam is trying hard while Ambassador Ells worth Bunker is in Washington to bring about a situation that the Americans regard as the worst possible: A one‐man presidential campaign with only Nguyen Van Thieu on the ballot.
author: By Raig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: CANDIDATES FEAR PHUOCLONG ROADS
McGeorge Bundy Sets Record Straight for Press
lead_paragraph: A handwritten message by McGeorge Bundy, President John F. Kennedy's adviser on national security, praising the vague wording of a 1963 press announcement on Vietnam policy, did not assert that such communiqués “should say nothing in such a way as to fool the press without deceiving them,” as reported last week in The New York Times.
author: By Henry Raymont

headline: HANOI UNITS ATTACK TWO BASES NEAR DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12 (AP)—North Vietnamese troops shelled and assaulted a South Vietnamese military district headquarters near the demilitarized zone early today, killing 10 defenders and wounding 10 others, the Saigon command reported,

headline: A.F.L.‐C.I.O. Parley Takes Strong Stand on Import
author: By Damon Stetson

headline: William P. Bundy Backed as Quarterly's Editor
lead_paragraph: David Rockefeller reaffirmed yesterday the appointment of William P. Bundy as editor of the quarterly journal Foreign Affairs.

headline: Black Power Group in Vietnam Fights Heroin Addiction, the Enemy Within
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 4 — “The Black Power movement in Nam was kicking off good in 1968, it had unity up to 1970, but that year I saw skag was going to be a problem and separate the Woods,” the black soldier said.
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Uncle Sweatshop
lead_paragraph: By almost every measure the draft is an odious business.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: CAMBODIA PLANNING A WINTER OFFENSIVE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) —Acting Premier Sisowath Sirik Matak said today that the Cambodian Army would mount a winter offensive with American air support and South Vietnamese ground forces against the Vietnamese Communists.

headline: Marine Who Was Held by Hanoi Found Not Guilty of All Charges
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 11— A young Long Island marine who spent 18 months as a prisoner of war was acquitted today of charges that he had run from his unit and, when captured, had made propaganda statements broadcast over the Hanoi radio.
author: By Walter Rugaber; Special to The New York Times

headline: KY REJECTS DECISION TO BAR CANDIDACY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said this morning that the Supreme Court decision that he had not qualified as a candidate for the presidential election on Oct. 3 was illegal and that he still considered himself a candidate.

headline: U.S. COMBAT DEATHS ROSE BY 4 IN WEEK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 (AP) — American battlefield deaths in Vietnam increased slightly last week but maintained the six‐year low that has prevailed for the past month, the United States Command reported today.

headline: PARIS PEACE TALKS NOW IN DOLDRUMS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Aug. 12—Xuan Thuy, suffering from what a spokesman termed “a slight indisposition,” did not represent North Vietnam today at the peace talks.
author: By Henry Giniger; Special to The New York Times

headline: WAR'S TIDE AND JOBS LINKED BY ROMNEY
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (UPI)— George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said tonight that more Americans were out of jobs because fewer were being killed in Vietnam.

headline: Army Investigates Alleged Atrocity by General
author: By Richard Halloran; Special to The New York Times

headline: Acquitted Marine Gets Honorable Discharge
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 12 (AP)— The Marine Corps gave Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney, 21 years old, an honorable discharge today.

headline: U.S. to Declassify More Secret Documents
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 — President Nixon has ordered early declassification of secret Government documents on the Korean war, the 1958 intervention by American troops in Lebanon, the abortive invasion of Cuba in 1961 and the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the White House announced today.

headline: Thousands of Vietnamese Told To Display Portrait of Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2—Hundreds of thousands of large photographs of President Nguyen Van Thieu, who is running for re‐election this October, are being handed out in the provinces by local officials who are ordering the, Vietnamese to display them.
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: P.O.W. Ads Facing Controversy
lead_paragraph: That Advertising Council campaign to focus attention on the plight of prisoners of war in Vietnam, awaited since it was announced in May, has become enmeshed in controversy. And the campaign—which is being prepared on behalf of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Mising‐In‐Action in Southeast Asia and the American Red Cross—isn't even ready to go yet.

headline: LAWYERS ASK NIXON TO RELEASE 3 AIRMEN
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Aug. 13—Lawyers for three Air Force enlisted men imprisoned in Vietnam for refusing to carry arms petitioned President Nixon today to release them pending appeal of their cases.

headline: Positions Just South of DMZ Shelled by Enemy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP) — North Vietnamese gunners fired more than 400 rockets and mortar shells into eight South Vietnamese positions along the demilitarized zone yesterday in an upsurge of fighting that has taken the lives of seven United States soldiers in a helicopter, military spokesmen said today.

headline: Americans Ordered to Avoid Saigon Ministry Till Election
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 (UPI) — The United States Embassy has ordered all American officials to stay away from the Vietnamese Government Information Service until Oct. 4. Sources said the reason for the action was that President Nguyen Van Thieu is using the service in his campaign for re‐election Oct. 3.

headline: Thieu Declares Ky Slanders South Vietnam's Institutions
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP)—President Nguyen Van Thieu accused Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today of having indulged in “groundless accusations and slanderings against national institutions. ”

headline: V.F.W. CHIEF EXPECTS P.O.W. RELEASES IN '71
lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Aug. 13 (UPI)— Herbert R. Rainwater, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said today he had “inside information” that some American prisoners of war would be released before Christmas.

headline: Reformist Montagnard Candidate for Assembly Says Vietnamese ‘Must Pay’
lead_paragraph: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 10—When Dinh Nai was a boy, typhoid was known among the Hre villagers in their dialect as Illness Lasting Long Time. There was no confusion about cholera because its victims died with their fingers curled or bent. Men hunted elephants with poison arrows. Children, to be healthy, wore no clothes.
author: By Gloria Emerson; Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There are two happy by‐products of the decision of The Times to publish the Pentagon papers: the action of the Kennedy Presidential Library In greatly expanding access to scholars and President Nixon's request for the declassification of the bulk of World War II documents.

headline: Staten Islander Elected
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 14 (AP) —Jerry Cohen of Staten Island, N.Y., was elected national com mander of the Jewish War Vet erans of the U.S.A. tonight. Mr. Cohen, who was decorated for his service with the Navy during World War II, led the fight for a resolution adopted yesterday urging withdrawal from Vietnam by Dec. 31. The group's national convention ended tonight.

headline: Lightship Going to War
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (UPI)—The Coast Guard light ship San Francisco, a mariner's beacon off the Golden Gate Bridge for 42 years until last April, has been pulled out of a short retirement for war duty in Vietnam. The 133‐foot, bath tub‐like vessel was towed out of the Hunters Point naval shipyard yesterday bound for Pearl Harbor. She will be towed to the Philippines to be out fitted for war duty.

headline: Peking's American Dilemma …
lead_paragraph: After two decades of angry complaint about the American presence in Asia, Communist China now ap peirs to be equally troubled by the prospects of Ameri can withdrawal.

headline: Laird to Seek $80‐Billion, Up $3‐Billion
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 14—De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that he would seek a defense budget of about $80‐ billion for the fiscal year be ginning July 1, 1972.

headline: Foe Attacks Village Near DMZ After Strikes on Allied Positions
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 15 (AP)—North Vietnamese forces attacked village south of the demili tarized zone early today in the fourth day of intensified fight ing in northena South Vietnam, the Saigon command said.

headline: Saigon Detains Taiwanese
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14 (Reuters)—The South Vietnamese Navy detained 14 fishermen from Taiwan for about two hours this week after they landed on one of the Paracel Islands, which are claimed by South Vietnam and Taiwan.

headline: 6 Presidential Hopefuls Stress Economic Issue at Texas Convention
lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Aug. 14 — “Mark my words,” Senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a rapt dinner audience of 1,500 Texans, “you have seen the next President of the United States.”
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: South Vietnam's Presidential election is still almost three months away but President Nguyen Van Thieu's supporters were already working last week for his re‐election. One of their moves was to distribute thou sands of copies of a large, glossy portrait of the 48‐year‐old leader, retouched to make him look younger and thinner than he is. Government officials in towns and villages were ordering in habitants to display the photo graph and to have it framed— at their own expense.

headline: Thieu Is Accused of Voting‐Card Fraud
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14—Gen. Duong Van Minh's campaign headquarters charged today that President Nguyen Van Thieu was trying to rig the presidential elections by issuing multiple voting cards to pro‐Government voters and in structing them to vote more than once.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Pentagon papers have made it quite obvious that the public and, to an extent, Congress were kept in the dark while two Presidents made and expanded commitments to Vietnam.

headline: V.F.W. CHIEF AMENDS REMARKS ON P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Aug. 14 (UPI)— Herbert R. Rainwater, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, denied last night that he had “inside informa tion” American prisoners of war in North Vietnam would be home before Christmas.

headline: Saigon's Often‐Ridiculed Deputies Off and Running
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14—The lower house of the South Vietnamese Legis lature sits in an ugly tin roofed building that was the opera house in French colon ial days. Political comic opera has been presented there rather frequently during the last four years.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: What is our specific commitment to South Vietnam as of now? Is it to up hold and protect the democratic proc ess or is there a continuing policy to which the public is not privy?

headline: In Vietnam, a Menu May Be French …but
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“If you want to make poulet a la creme, there aren't any good mushrooms. You can't make Swiss fondue because there's no cheese or kirsch. Two years ago they stopped importing wines. But I suppose we shouldn't com plain. There's a war on,” said Madame Madeleine Leccia, proprietor of the Guillaume fell restaurant in Saigon.
author: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu's Political Brinkmanship
lead_paragraph: The recall of Ambassador Bunker to Washington for consultations reflects the dangerous situation that has arisen in South Vietnam's presidential election campaign. There is a widespread belief that President Thieu is rigging the election—most blatantly through the maneu vers used to block the candidacy of the country's Vice President, Air Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky. Threats of with drawal are being made by the only remaining challenger, Gen. Duong Van (Big) Minh, and many of his backers.

headline: Cambodia Is Planning To Replace Saigon Units
lead_paragraph: PNOM PENH, Cambodia, Monday, Aug. 15 (Reuters)— The Cambodian high com mand announced today that plans were being worked out for the withdrawal of South Vietnamese ttoops from their major base of operations along the Mekong River.

headline: J.W.V. Elects Commander
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 15 (UPI) —Jerry Cohen of Staten Island, a highly decorated veteran of World War II who campaigns to have the Jewish War Vet erans change its stand on the war in Southeast Asia has been elected national commander o the group. He told the group's convention yesterday that he would give first priority to the problems facing eterans re turning from Vietnam.

headline: Evidence to Be Presented Today in Trial of Medina
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 15 (UPI)—Capt. Ernest L. Me dina, accused of over‐all respon sibility for the mass killing at Mylai, faces a court‐martial to morrow, three years and five months after his infantry com pany swept through the South Vietnamese hamlet.

headline: U.S. Raids in Zone Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Aug. 15 (UPI) — American sources said today that B‐52 bombers have been making unannounced strikes against enemy supply lines in the southern half of the demili tarized zone this month for the first time since the 1968 halt of the bombing campaign against North Vietnam.

headline: This Is John Doe, Unknown Soldier
lead_paragraph: WARRINGTON—The somber President, dressed in black, strode to the podium In the East Room of the White Rouse and announced to the press corps that hostilities in Vietnam had ended at exactly 4:32 P.M: (our time).
author: BY Benjamin Kluger

headline: U.S. WARNS HANOI OVER DE ACTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15—The United States com mand said today that it viewed with “deep concern” enemy activity along the demilitarized zone and threatened retaliatory action against the North Viet namese.

headline: Eisenhower and Diem
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn.—Several years ago—long after I had left Washing ton, long after President Johnson had sent thousands upon thousands of American troops into Vietnam, long after hundreds of them had died there in battle—the phone rang on a warm summer Saturday afternoon at my home here.
author: By William Bragg Ewald Jr

headline: Prosecution Says That Medina ‘Chose Not to Intervene’ at Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 16—Capt. Ernest L. Me dina did not order the mass killings at Mylai but he “cal culatingly chose not to inter vene” while his troops were killing unarmed civilians, the military prosecutor said today in opening the Government's case against the 34‐year‐old Mexican‐American officer.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In responding to my July 20 Op‐Ed article, Eric Sevareid is right in say ing that Senator Hartke and I did not have exclusive knowledge that the Johnson Administration's Vietnam spending in 1966 was far above the publicized figures, or even those re luctantly admitted to in private. [Let ter July 31]. He did indeed do yeo men service in circulating early evi dence of the widening credibility gap; and many a bemused economist read ing Government handouts both then and now (beginning with the budget itself), might profit by a gaze as ques tioning and a mind as independent.

headline: China Seems to Soothe Allies on U.S.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Aug. 16— Neighboring governments sup ported bysthe Chinese Commu nists appear to have lost some of the apprehension they initial lge showed over Peking's new policy of contact with the United States.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: CAMBODIANS TO ASK ’72 SAIGON PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak, the Acting Premier of Cambodia, said here esterday that his Government would ask South Vietnam to withdraw its troops from Cambodia by June, 1972.

headline: Ellsberg Denies Guilt, Will Fight
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16—Dr., Daniel Ellsberg pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had illegally possessed and copied the controversial Penta gon papers.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: Attack hi North Reported
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) —A United States Phantom jet attacked an antiaircraft‐gun po sition in North Vietnam yester day after a reconnaissance plane taking photographs had been fired on near the North Vietnamese coast, about 15 miles north of the DMZ, an American spokesman said to day.

headline: Johnson and Nixon Given Lower Rating in War Poll
lead_paragraph: Publication of the Pentagon papers on Vietnam has lowered the credibility ratings of both former President Lyndon B. Johnson and. President Nixon, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday.

headline: Vietcong Sink Vessel
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, Aug. 17 (AP)—Vietcong frogmen blew up and sank the United States cargo vessel Green Bay early today at Quinhon harbor, 250 miles northeast of Saigon. First reports listed casualties as four injured, one identified as an American. The vessel was re ported to be carrying supplies for post exchanges.

headline: Foe Seizes Post Near DMZ, Inflicting Heavy Losses
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10—North Vietnamese troops overran a South Vietnamese Marine company's mountaintop outpost south of the demilitar ized zone yesterday and in flicted heavy losses on the Gov ernment troops, the South Viet namese command announced today.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: TIMES TO PUBLISH JOHNSON MEMOIRS
lead_paragraph: The New York Times, has ac quired the syndication iights to the memoirs of former Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson, and will publish excerpts in The Times starting Oct. 17.

headline: Ky Supporter in Saigon Ignites Himself in Protest
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (AP)—A Vietnamese war veteran set himself afire at a main intersection today to protest Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's disquali fication from the presidential election Oct. 3.

headline: U.S. Acknowledges Raids By B‐52's in Buffer Zone
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Atig. 17—The United States command acknowledged today for the first time that Ameri can B‐52 bombing raids had been flown in the southern half of the demilitarized zone at the border between North Vietnam and South Vietnam.

headline: Church Plans 4‐Book Version of Pentagon Study
lead_paragraph: The Beacon Press, a non profit publishing branch of the Unitarian Universalist Associa tion, announced yesterday that it would publish a 3,000‐page, four‐volume version of the Pentagon's secret study of United States involvement in Indochina.

headline: Nine Witnesses Unable to Place Medina at Site of Mylai Slayings
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 17— Men whose testimony helped convict Frist Lieut. Wil liam L. Caney Jr. gave an other recital today of the de tails of the Mylai mass killings. They appeared ha Government witnesses in the court‐martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who commanded the troops involved in the incident.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Artillery Moves Up
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Aug. 18 (AP) — American artillerymen moved west along the demilitarized zone yesterday to sup port South Vietnamese troops in the sixth day of a North Viet namese drive.

headline: SAIGON GETS 18 BIDS FOR OIL EXPLORATION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (UPI) — Eighteen oil companies have bid on conces sion rights for offshore petro leum exploration on the con tinental shelf in the South China Sea, the Government news organ, Vietnam Press, an nounced today.

headline: The Military and Morality
lead_paragraph: Presidents Johnson and Kennedy sent half a million soldiers to Vietnam. President Nixon is bringing home 14,000 a month (230,000 are left now). Meanwhile, some erstwhile Kennedy‐ Johnson supporters want to impeach Mr. Nixon. Our soldiers are accused not only of waging anlunjust war but also of “war crimes” and our corn manders of ordering or condoning them. While the enemy has repudiated them, we have recognized the “laws and customs of war” as binding. They do not avoid the horrors of war, but they do restrict the evil they cannot eliminate. Have we violated them?
author: By Ernest van Den Haag

headline: Judge to Rule on Testimony In Colonel's Trial on Mylai
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 17 (AP)—A military judge has promised to rule on a defense motion just 30 minutes before Col. Oran K. Henderson of the Army goes on trial on charges of trying to conceal the Mylai mass killings.

headline: ARMY WILL PUNISH 9 IN MYLAI AFFAIR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) —Secretary of the Army Rob ert F. Froelke has ordered new disciplinary action against nine officers and enlisted men pre viously cleared of criminal charges stemming from the, Mylai mass killings.

headline: Judge Asks Study of Charge That Jail Mistreated Russo
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) —A Federal judge ordered an investigation today into allegations that Anthony J. Russo, who refused to testify in the leaking of the secret Pentagon papers, has been mistreated in jail.

headline: Washington Comments
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) —The State Department press officer, Robert J. McCloskey, said today that the announced withdrawal of Australian and New Zealand troops from Vietnam was “in harmony with our own withdrawal program and the Vietnamization effort.”

headline: Hanoi Reports Victory
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 18 (Agence France‐Presse)—According to a military commentator here. North Vietnamese forces have succeeded’ in piercing South Vietnam's northern defenses at several points along Route 9.

headline: MEDINA IS PLACED AT SLAYING SCENE
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 18—The alleged slaying of several Vietnamese children, one of them in the presence of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, was described today at the 34‐year‐old officer's court‐martial.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Proxy Wars in Indochina
lead_paragraph: The State Department has replied with a non sequitur to Congressional criticism of United States support for Thai soldiers fighting in Laos. The department argued the other day that it was entitled to withhold compliance from the Geneva accord neutralizing Laos because of what it termed massive violations of neutrality by 80,000 North Vietnamese now in that country.

headline: Army Clears U.S. Soldiers In Cambodia Hospital Case
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) — The Army said today that it had found no evidence of misconduct by United States troops after investigating charges that they shelled a Vietcong hospital complex in Cambodia in February, 1969.

headline: Saigon Reports 142 of Foe Killed in Battle Near DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command, today reported that 142 North Vietnamese and 22 South Viet namese had been killed in the biggest battle in months just below the demilitarized zone.

headline: Treated in U.S., Vietnamese Returns Home
lead_paragraph: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 8—“Your legs, are they wood or real?” the elderly Vietnamese in soiled garments asked.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Australia and New Zealand To Quit Vietnam This Year
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 —Australia and New Zealand announced today that they would withdraw their combat forces from South Vietnam in the next few months.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Casualties Down For 5th Week in Row
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 (AP)—American casualties in Vietnam remained at a low level last week while South Vietnamese losses rose sharply, the allied commands reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp's Aug. Op‐Ed article criticizing both The New York Times version of the Pentagon papers and the restrictions placed on the air war against North Vietnam reflects one of the chief fallacies in the thinking of the military mind: The inability to understand the chain of events set into motion by the excessive use of power.

headline: Minh Quits Vietnam Race, Saying Thieu Rigs Election
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 20—Gen. Duong Van Minh withdrew from the presidential race this morning, leaving President Nguyen Van Thieu unopposed in the elections scheduled for Oct. 3.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon May Be Asked to Intervene in Medina Trial
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 19 — The possibility that President Nixon may be asked to intervene in the Mylai courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina was raised today by F. Lee Bailey, the defense counsel.
author: By Homer Bigart. Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: A.B.C. to Focus on G.I. Casualty—Drug Abuse
lead_paragraph: Narcotics addiction among United States servicemen in Vietnam—a couple of months ago, in a flurry of headlines, cover stories and television specials, the subject was “hot.” Then, following appropriate expressions of deep concern and official studies indicating that the problem was being ?? in the media, thc, same subject's news value tinned noticeably cool. The problem, unfortunately, is still hot.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: Underworld Contributor
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHBRSON, Ga., Aug. 19 (UPI) — Mr. Bailey announced today that Peter J. Lazaros, a self‐described “fixer” for the underworld, in the Detroit area, had contributed “several thousand dollars” to Captain Medina's legal defense fund.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Fourteen newspapers in eluding The Denver Post and The Houston Chronicle have now dropped the column “On the Right,” by William F. Buckley Jr. The cancellations continue in the wake of publication, in Mr. Buckley's magazine National Review of fictitious Vietnam war secrets. Reports of the “secret papers” were carried by wire services and published by newspapers across the country before Mr. Buckley disclosed that it was all a hoax. Reached yesterday for comment on the most recent cancellations Mr. Buckley said he was “surprised” but he composed, ex nihilo a statement:

headline: A Bitter Little War Raging Just Below the DMZ
lead_paragraph: ??UANGTRI, South Vietnam, Aug; 19—The B‐52 bombers trace their thin, white jet trails over the Quangtri combat base every day, making a U‐turn just to the north and then heading back to their bases in Thailand again, before the tons of bombs thunder into the ground just below the demilitarized zone and send clouds of dus drifting toward the South China Sea.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Ky Allowed to Enter Race In Saigon Court Reversal
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 21—The Supreme Court reversed itself in a surprise decision today and agreed to allow the presidential candidacy of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley Juror Says Verdict Offered Few Options
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 20—A juror in the court‐martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that the officer's life sentence, now substantially reduced, might have been lighter in the first place had the six officers who found him guilty of murder had such an alternative.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: The Calley Review
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor, the first officer to review the Calley case, finds the original conviction to be “correct in law and fact.” The general nevertheless considers it “appropriate for the offense for which he was convicted” to reduce Lieutenant Calley's life sentence to twenty years’ imprisonment, thus making him eligible for parole in six to seven years.

headline: Ky Marches in Funeral
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 20 — The crippled war veteran who burned himself to death Monday to protest Government election policies was given a large public funeral today while rumors of more political disturbances circulated in Saigon following Gen. Duong Van Minh's withdrawal from the presidential campaign.

headline: Witness Says He Didn't Report Mylai Civilian Deaths to Medina
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 20 (AP)—A former Charlie Company platoon leader testified today that he came across the bodies of civilians soon after entering Mylai but did not report his discovery to Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the company commander.

headline: Attorneys General and Lawyers Map Drive on Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Aug. 20—In an unlikely meeting of legal minds, assistant attorneys general from Massachusetts and Minnesota and the attorney general of New Mexico gathered here this week with leading civil rights lawyers and antiwar activists to map a joint assault on the war in Vietnam.
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: B‐52'S JOIN DRIVE TO SLOW ENEMY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 21 (AP)— Six waves of United States B‐52 bombers pounded South Vietnam's embattled northern front today in stepped‐up raids designed to slow a 10‐day‐old North Vietnamese offensive.

headline: ANTI‐THIEU ACTION BY U.S. DOUBTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 —The Nixon Administration expressed regret today over the withdrawal of General Duong Van Minh from the South Vietnamese presidential race.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR STUDENTS LAUDED BY ELLSBERG
lead_paragraph: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 20 — Daniel Ellsberg said last night that student antiwar activities were responsible acts and set an example for him in his release to the American press of the Pentagon papers.

headline: GALLEY SENTENCE IS CUT TO 20 YEARS FROM LIFE TERM
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga, Aug. 20—The life sentence of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was ordered reduced to 20 years today by Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor; the commanding general of the Third Army.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Supreme Court Recalls French Colonial Period
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 21—Shortly after one o'clock, the nine Supreme Court justices in their ,red silk and ermine‐trimmed robes filed into courtroom, converted from the ornate but slightly seedy ballroom of a gently decaying French colonial palace.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: The five‐inch guns of American guided missile destroyers and bombs from high‐flying American B‐52 aircraft have been pounding the six‐mile wide, 45‐mile long demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam. headline: Screen: Coutard Focuses on Vietnam in 'Hoa-Binh':Rhetoric of War Fades in Face of Reality Boy Left to Find Way in a Scarred World
lead_paragraph: Among cinematographers younger than 50 there is probably none more internationally famous or more justly famous than Raoul Coutard, who has photographed most of the greatest films of François Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard. So highly is Coutard regarded that some critics unfriendly to the French New Wave have speculated that the real genius behind films like "Une Femme Est une Femme" and "La Chinoise" was the photographer and not the director at all. For this line of reasoning to be laid to rest, I suppose it would be necessary for Coutard to make his own movie, and this he has now done. It is called "Hoa-Binh," and it opened yesterday at the Lincoln Art Theater.In many respects it is very much a photographer's movie. Looking not at all like Truffaut or Godard, it is full of muted colors, striking images that seem to have been included for their own sake, and details held in splendid isolation — as the camera rather than the eye might see them. All of which gives "Hoa-Binh" a curiously old-fashioned and rather artlessly handsome look not entirely inconsistent with the moods of its story—which is, however, set in the midst of the modern and unlovely reality of contemporary South Vietnam.Although it was made under the shadow of, and is necessarily about, the war in Vietnam, "Hoa-Binh" goes to almost excruciating lengths to avoid propagandistic persuasion. And although its locations are actual and its actors mostly amateur, it has a story, and its reality is the reality of fiction and not of documentary.The hero is named Hung, an 11-year-old boy whose father goes off to join the Vietcong and whose mother shortly afterward is hospitalized with terminal cancer. The sole protector of his baby sister, Hung soon leaves the unfriendly cousin with whom he has been placed and begins to make his way in the young-people's free-enterprise world of Saigon. He tries his hand at stevedoring and gambling, at which he does well; and at shoe-shining and newspaper-selling, at which he does badly.In general, the children's fortunes decline, but in the knick of time a nurse, a total stranger, takes them in, gives Hung shelter, gets him a job, and places the baby in a nursery. Meanwhile from the North, Hung's father begins a journey home, to deliver messages and to begin again with what is left of his family.I'm not sure that any movie based on a fiction so limited and, in a sense, so gratuitous, could be wholly satisfactory. "Hoa-Binh" adds to its simplicities a kind of hapless awkwardness in execution, in the mechanics of simply carrying a scene through. And at the same time it introduces ideological material—a humane justification of the American presence overheard from an Army sergeant while Hung shines his shoes; an organizer's lucid promise of Vietcong victory while United States jets roar overhead—that it is not really prepared to digest except in terms of obvious ironic illustration of the futility of high thought in a world of low feeling and of intensely personal privations.But "Hoa-Binh" ultimately succeeds beneath the play of ideology, and despite its structural crudities, and even despite the indulgences that Coutard sometimes allows his camera. For it is a deeply honorable work, as honorable in its refusal to place blame as in its decency in the face of human suffering. In this it achieves a moral reticence that approaches asceticism and that is as beautiful to watch in the movies as anywhere else.You can see it most clearly perhaps in the lovely performances of Phi Lan as Hung and Xuan Ha as his young mother. If you watch their eyes you will see that their looks and glances, wonderful in themselves, are used not to externalize suffering and so engage the audience's sympathy, but to communicate and so build a world of shared understanding—even though that understanding may include not only love but also fear and hate.The result is a self-sufficiency that begs no responses, but that is moving in some of the ways that film can be moving—without at the same time losing its bearings and pretending that it is life. Anyone can imagine a dozen movies about Vietnam, full of searing indictments and heartbreaking revelations. But "Hoa-Binh" is none of these. With all its faults it is something very much better, more complete, more secret, more genuinely in touch with the mysteries of human perception.
author: By Roger Greenspun

headline: Movies
lead_paragraph: IF there is such a thing as a film that makes its viewer a better human being—and I dearly hope there is—“Hoa Binh” is it. It is the story, essentially, of two Vietnamese children: a boy, Hung, aged 11, and his sister, Xuan, one‐and‐a‐half. The time is not now or last year or tomorrow; the time is, simply and dreadfully, war. The action takes place between Hung's father's de parture to join the Viet Cong and his return, months later, to Saigon. In between, Hung loses his mother, must sur vive against terrifying odds in the war‐mauled city while also taking care of baby Xuan, and must not give up hope. It is a tall order for a little boy, but with some help and much hindrance from others, he does it. “Hoa Binh” tells it without the slightest histrionics, without striving for pathos, or excess of any kind.

headline: State of Alert Lifted
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Tuesday, Aug. 31 (Reuters)—The general state of alert imposed for one week on American troops in Vietnam was lifted at dawn today, an American military spokesman said. Individual units could be kept on alert if their command er decided it was necessary, but the 9,000 American service men in the Saigon area were free to leave their barracks for the first time.

headline: Withdrawal of 42,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 (UPI)—The United States command will withdraw 42,000 American soldiers from Vietnam during a three‐month period beginning Wednesday to meet President Nixon's Dec. 1 deadline for cutting troop strength to 184,000, military sources said today.
